{{Infobox comics creator | image = Adam Kubert.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | birth_date = October 6, 1959 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | pencil = y | ink = y | alias = | notable works = ''[[Action Comics]]''
''[[The Incredible Hulk (comic book)|The Incredible Hulk]]''
''[[Ultimate X-Men]]''
''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' | awards = [[Eisner Award]], 1992 | influences = [[Joe Kubert]] | subcat = American}} '''Adam Kubert''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|juː|b|ər|t}}; born 1959){{cite web |url= http://www.lambiek.net/artists/k/kubert_adam.htm|title= Adam Kubert|date= October 8, 2010|publisher= [[Lambiek|Lambiek Comiclopedia]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131014041034/http://www.lambiek.net/artists/k/kubert_adam.htm|archivedate= October 14, 2013|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|accessdate= January 10, 2014}} is an American [[comics artist]] known for his work for publishers such as [[Marvel Comics]] and [[DC Comics]], including work on ''[[Action Comics]]'', ''[[Astonishing Spider-Man & Wolverine]]'', ''[[The Incredible Hulk (comic book)|The Incredible Hulk]]'', ''[[Ultimate Fantastic Four]]'', ''[[Ultimate X-Men]]'', and ''[[Wolverine (comic book)|Wolverine]]''. Kubert was rated by ''[[Wizard (magazine)|Wizard]]'' magazine as one of the "Hot 10 Writers and Artists" in the industry in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.wizarduniverse.com/021208hot10artists.html|title= Hot 10 Writers & Artists|accessdate= April 3, 2008|work= [[Wizard (magazine)|Wizard]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080427005827/http://www.wizarduniverse.com/021208hot10artists.html|archivedate = April 27, 2008|deadurl= yes|df=mdy-all}} He is the son of [[Joe Kubert]] and brother of [[Andy Kubert]], both comic book artists as well, and the uncle of comics editor [[Katie Kubert]].{{cite web |url= http://www.newsarama.com/21348-nycc-se-2014-marvel-next-big-thing-panel-live.html|title= NYCC SE 2014: Marvel: Next Big Thing Panel - ''Fantastic Four'' 2015 News, Much More|first= Lucas|last= Siegel|date= June 14, 2014|publisher= [[Newsarama]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140809105322/http://www.newsarama.com/21348-nycc-se-2014-marvel-next-big-thing-panel-live.html|archivedate= August 9, 2014|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |url= http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/06/14/two-dc-comics-editors-leave-one-to-marvel-one-to-valiant/|title= Two DC Comics Editors Leave – One To Marvel, One To Valiant (Update x2)|first= Rich|last= Johnston|authorlink= Rich Johnston|date= June 14, 2014|publisher= Bleeding Cool|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714192201/http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/06/14/two-dc-comics-editors-leave-one-to-marvel-one-to-valiant/|archivedate= July 14, 2014|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}} Born in [[Dover, New Jersey]] he is an instructor at the [[Joe Kubert School]] located there, which Joe Kubert founded, and at which he and Andy studied.{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/14/nyregion/paper-pencil-and-a-dream.html?pagewanted=all|title= Paper, Pencil And a Dream|first= Dana|last= Jennings|date= December 14, 2003|publisher= ''[[The New York Times]]''|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130521085309/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/14/nyregion/paper-pencil-and-a-dream.html?pagewanted=all|archivedate= May 21, 2013|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|accessdate= March 29, 2012|quote= Mr. Kubert said that Dover, which has 18,000 people and is bisected by the Rockaway River, suits him. He and his wife, Muriel, raised their five children here, and it was here that they opened their school.}} ==Early life== Adam Kubert is the son of Muriel (née Fogelson) and Joe Kubert. His siblings include a sister, Lisa, and brothers David, Daniel, and [[Andy Kubert|Andrew]].{{cite web |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3413900173.html?key=01-42160D527E1B10681003021F076904332953225E20212F592C5B4C23291A607F127119731A7B1D6B75170028|title= Kubert, Joe, 1926-|date= n.d.|publisher= [[HighBeam Research]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130517194526/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3413900173.html?key=01-42160D527E1B10681003021F076904332953225E20212F592C5B4C23291A607F127119731A7B1D6B75170028|archivedate= May 17, 2013|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|accessdate= August 13, 2012}} Comics editor Katie Kubert is his niece. He and his siblings grew up in [[Dover, New Jersey]]. He began his professional comics career at age 12 as a [[letterer]]. He attended the [[Rochester Institute of Technology]] and graduated with a degree in [[medical illustration]]. He subsequently attended his father's [[The Kubert School]] in Dover, New Jersey.{{cite journal|title = WonderCon Special Guests|journal = Comic-Con Magazine|page = 19|publisher = [[San Diego Comic-Con International]]|date = Winter 2010|url = http://issuu.com/comic-con/docs/ccmag_winter2010}}{{cite web |url= http://www.kubertschool.edu/faculty/Adam_Kubert.html|title= Adam Kubert, Illustrator, Comic Book Illustrator and VP|date= n.d.|publisher= [[The Kubert School]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140111053639/http://www.kubertschool.edu/faculty/Adam_Kubert.html|archivedate= January 11, 2014|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|accessdate= November 13, 2011}} ==Career== Adam Kubert began his comics career as a letterer for DC Comics. His first credited artwork for the company is the story "Gremlins" published in ''[[Sgt. Rock]]'' #394 (Nov. 1984).{{gcdb|type=credit|search=Adam+Kubert|title=Adam Kubert}} In 1988, Adam Kubert drew the ''[[Jezebel Jade]]'' limited series, a spin-off from the ''[[Jonny Quest]]'' series, for [[Comico: The Comic Company|Comico]].{{cite journal|last= Stroud|first= Bryan D.|title= William Messner-Loebs and Adam Kubert Discuss ''Jezebel Jade''|journal= [[Back Issue!]]|issue= 90|pages= 68–75|publisher= [[TwoMorrows Publishing]]|date= August 2016|location= Raleigh, North Carolina}} He collaborated with his brother on ''[[Adam Strange]]'' (1990){{cite book|last=Manning|first= Matthew K.|last2=Dolan|first2=Hannah, ed.|chapter= 1990s|title = DC Comics Year By Year A Visual Chronicle|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]]|year=2010|location= London, United Kingdom|isbn= 978-0-7566-6742-9|page= 244|quote = Told in a sophisticated voice by writer Richard Bruning, all three volumes [of ''Adam Strange''] were illustrated by brothers and future comics superstars Andy and Adam Kubert.}} and the ''[[Batman versus Predator]]'' [[intercompany crossover]] (1992). ===Marvel Comics=== [[Image:Uncanny377.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Cover to ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' #377 (Feb. 2000). Art by Adam Kubert.]] Adam Kubert is known for his work at Marvel Comics. From 1993 to 1996 he illustrated 17 issues of writer [[Larry Hama]]'s run on ''[[Wolverine (comic book)|Wolverine]]'' between issues #75 to 102. His first issue on the series featured the after affects of [[Magneto (comics)|Magneto]] removing the [[adamantium]] from Wolverine's body.{{cite book|last = Manning|first = Matthew K.|last2= Gilbert|first2= Laura, ed.|chapter= 1990s|title = Marvel Chronicle A Year by Year History|publisher = [[Dorling Kindersley]]|year = 2008|location= London, United Kingdom|page = 265|isbn =978-0756641238|quote= In ''Wolverine'' #75, Wolverine was left a shell of his former self, barely surviving Magneto's attack...thanks to writer Larry Hama and penciller Adam Kubert.}} Kubert drew the ''Weapon X'' limited series as part of the "[[Age of Apocalypse]]" storyline in 1995.Manning "1990s" in Gilbert (2008), p. 273 The following year, he drew the ''[[Onslaught (comics)|Onslaught: X-Men]]'' and ''Onslaught: Marvel Universe'' one-shots which lead into the "[[Heroes Reborn (comics)|Heroes Reborn]]" crossover.Manning "1990s" in Gilbert (2008), p. 280: "Onslaught truly rose to power in the ''Onslaught: X-Men'' special by writers Mark Waid and Scott Lobdell and artist Adam Kubert." From 1997 to 1998 he illustrated 12 issues of [[Peter David]]'s run on ''[[The Incredible Hulk (comic book)|The Incredible Hulk]]'' from #454 to 467, as well as the -1 issue (July 1997). From late 1998 to early 1999 Kubert drew ''[[X-Men: Legacy|X-Men]]'' #81 - 84, on which he was teamed up with European colorist [[Richard Isanove]], who subsequently followed Kubert to ''Ultimate X-Men'', employing the pencils-to-color approach seen on most of ''Ultimate X-Men'' covers. In 2001, Kubert drew the new ''[[Ultimate X-Men]]'' title,Manning "2000s" in Gilbert (2008), p. 304: "Looking to repeat the success of ''Ultimate Spider-Man'' in 2000, the second major title of this alternate universe was crafted by esteemed writer Mark Millar along with the famed Kubert brothers, Andy and Adam, taking turns at the drawing table." penciling the first four issues, and then illustrating 16 various issues beginning with #7, before leaving the title with issue #33 (July 2003). In 2004, he began a run on ''[[Ultimate Fantastic Four]]'', once again with writers Mark Millar and [[Brian Michael Bendis]],Manning "2000s" in Gilbert (2008), p. 320: "Ultimate veterans Brian Michael Bendis, Mark Millar, and Adam Kubert reexamined Marvel's first family, creating this alternate version of the Fantastic Four." illustrating that series' first six issues, and then issues 13-18. ===DC Comics=== Both Adam and his brother Andy signed exclusive contracts with DC Comics in June 2005.{{cite web |url= http://www.comicbookbin.com/comicbooknews027.html|title= Artists Adam and Andy Kubert Sign 3-Year Exclusive Agreements With DC Comics|date= June 6, 2005|publisher= Comic Book Bin|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140111060533/http://www.comicbookbin.com/comicbooknews027.html|archivedate= January 11, 2014|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |url= http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=14947|title= Lying In The Gutters|first= Rich|last= Johnston|authorlink = Rich Johnston|date= June 7, 2005|publisher= [[Comic Book Resources]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120728184934/http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=14947|archivedate= July 28, 2012|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|quote= The Kubert Brothers' exclusive deal with DC Comics was announced at the weekend. What was not announced was that they will be working on the ''Detective Comics'' series, with scripts written by Grant Morrison.}} Kubert's first project for DC was illustrating "[[Last Son (comics)|Last Son]]", a [[Superman]] story arc co-written by [[Geoff Johns]] and [[Richard Donner]], which ran in ''[[Action Comics]]'' #844–847, 851 and ''Action Comics Annual'' #11. Further delay forced DC Comics to bring in substitute creative teams and delay the fourth part of the "Last Son" storyline and the [[Stereoscopy|3D issue]] to #851, which was released in early July 2007. The final part of the storyline was in ''Action Comics Annual'' #11.{{cite web |url= http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=108943|title= More ''Action Comics'' Scheduling Woes|first= Matt|last= Brady|date= April 15, 2007|publisher= Newsarama|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070929121738/http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=108943|archivedate= September 29, 2007|deadurl= yes|df=mdy-all|accessdate= April 3, 2008|quote= A note to let everyone know that our "Last Son" finale has been moved to ''Action Comics Annual'' #11 to accommodate Adam [Kubert]'s schedule and allow us to continue on with our ''Action Comics'' run.}} Following his work on Superman he penciled the "[[Final Crisis]]" tie-in, ''DC Universe: Last Will and Testament'', written by [[Brad Meltzer]].{{cite web |url= http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=16693|title= Meltzer Bridges ''Final Crisis'' with ''Last Will and Testament'|first= Jeffrey|last= Renaud|date= June 4, 2008|publisher= Comic Book Resources|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121006203545/http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=16693|archivedate= October 6, 2012|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite book|last= Manning|first= Matthew K.|last2=Dougall|first2=Alastair, ed.|chapter= 2000s|title= Batman: A Visual History|publisher= [[Dorling Kindersley]]|year= 2014|location= London, United Kingdom|page= 301|isbn= 978-1465424563|quote= Geo-Force, founding member of the Outsiders, starred in this one-shot special thanks to writer Brad Meltzer and artist Adam Kubert.}} His last work for his latest tenure at DC was the ''Batman and The Outsiders Special,'' released in February 2009. This issue, written by [[Peter Tomasi]], highlighted [[Alfred Pennyworth]]'s efforts to recruit a new team of Outsiders in the wake of [[Batman]]'s apparent death.Manning "2000s" in Dougall, p. 303: "In this one-shot scripted by new series writer Peter J. Tomasi and illustrated by Adam Kubert, Alfred Pennyworth assembled a new team of Outsiders." After the release of the comic book, Kubert said he was pleased with his work at DC and had done, "what [he] set out to do," which was to draw Superman.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/15933-adam-kubert-talks-batman-and-the-outsiders-nycc-2009.html |title=Adam Kubert Talks ''Batman and The Outsiders'' @ NYCC 2009 |year=2009 |publisher=Newsarama |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6MYqN0T3X?url=http://www.newsarama.com/15933-adam-kubert-talks-batman-and-the-outsiders-nycc-2009.html |archivedate=January 12, 2014 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }} ===Return to Marvel=== May 2009 marked Adam Kubert's return to Marvel, his first interior work being published as one of two stories in ''[[Wolverine (comic book)|Wolverine]]'' #73 and 74.{{cite web |url= http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=1001|title= Review of ''Wolverine'' #73|first= Benjamin|last= Birdie|date= May 13, 2009|publisher= Comic Book Resources|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121009013119/http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=1001|archivedate= October 9, 2012|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}} Archive requires scrolldown Following this he contributed several covers to ''[[New Mutants]]'' and ''Wolverine: Weapon X'', and penciled the "[[Dark Reign (comics)|Dark Reign]]" tie in, ''The List: Amazing [[Spider-Man]]''.{{cite web |url= http://marvel.com/comics/issue/27417/dark_reign_-_the_list_amazing_spider-man_one-shot_2009_1|title= ''Dark Reign - The List: Amazing Spider-Man'' One-Shot (2009) #1|date= November 18, 2009|publisher= Marvel Comics|accessdate= April 1, 2010}} When he returned to penciling for Marvel, he continued to do some work for DC, contributing the stories for the ''[[Wednesday Comics]]'' "[[Sgt. Rock]]" feature, drawn by his father.Cowsill, Alan "2000s" in Dolan, p. 338: "The [series] contained fifteen continuous stories, including a new Sgt. Rock saga drawn by the legendary Joe Kubert and written by his son Adam." He has since stated that he is Marvel-exclusive, but they are allowed him to work on the "Sgt. Rock" feature as he had signed on to do it before his contract at DC had expired.{{cite web |url= http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=22150|title= ''Wednesday Comics'': The Kuberts|first= Jeffrey|last= Renaud|date= July 22, 2009|publisher= Comic Book Resources|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140111071217/http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=22150|archivedate= January 11, 2014|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|quote= This was just an exception. I let them know this was something that I was working on prior to going to Marvel and I wanted to keep doing it.}} Kubert's next job was providing pencils on ''[[Astonishing Spider-Man & Wolverine]]''.{{cite web |url= http://marvel.com/comics/issue/31210/astonishing_spider-manwolverine_2010_1|title= ''Astonishing Spider-Man/Wolverine'' (2010) #1|date= May 5, 2010|publisher= Marvel Comics|accessdate= October 16, 2012}} In 2012, Kubert penciled issues #8–10 and #12 of the Marvel crossover miniseries ''[[Avengers vs. X-Men]]''. He then drew issues #4–6 of [[Jonathan Hickman]]'s run on ''[[The Avengers (comic book)|The Avengers]]''. In June 2017, Kubert began penciling ''Peter Parker: The Spectacular Spider-Man'' written by [[Chip Zdarsky]]. The revamped title being billed as a “back-to-basics” approach for the character.{{cite web|url= http://ew.com/books/2017/02/14/chip-zdarsky-peter-parker-spectacular-spider-man/|title= Chip Zdarsky's ''Peter Parker: The Spectacular Spider-Man'' goes back to basics|first= Christian|last= Holub|date= February 14, 2017|work= [[Entertainment Weekly]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170722140830/http://ew.com/books/2017/02/14/chip-zdarsky-peter-parker-spectacular-spider-man/|archivedate= July 22, 2017|deadurl= no|df= mdy-all|quote= Marvel fans have been clamoring for a return to the wall-crawler’s down-on-his-luck days. That’s what they’re getting with ''Peter Parker: The Spectacular Spider-Man'', the new series from writer Chip Zdarsky and artist Adam Kubert.}}{{cite web|url= https://www.newsarama.com/35033-best-shots-review-peter-parker-spectacular-spider-man-1-strong-quick-witted-9-10.html|title= Best Shots Review: ''Peter Parker: Spectacular Spider-Man'' #1 'Strong & Quick-Witted' (9/10)|first= Oscar|last= Maltby|date= June 21, 2017|publisher= Newsarama|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170621220043/https://www.newsarama.com/35033-best-shots-review-peter-parker-spectacular-spider-man-1-strong-quick-witted-9-10.html|archivedate= June 21, 2017|deadurl= no|df= mdy-all|quote= Chip Zdarsky and Adam Kubert prove that nothing beats the solid fundamentals with ''Peter Parker: Spectacular Spider-Man'' #1, a colorful mix of the old and new }} ===Teaching work=== Kubert and his brother Andy teach at [[The Kubert School]], which was founded by their father, who also taught there before his passing in 2012. ==Awards== *1992 [[Eisner Award]] for Best Inker for ''[[Batman versus Predator]]''{{cite web |url= http://www.hahnlibrary.net/comics/awards/eisner92.php|title= 1992 Will Eisner Comic Industry Award Nominees and Winners |publisher= Hahn Library Comic Book Awards Almanac|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131108062641/http://www.hahnlibrary.net/comics/awards/eisner92.php|archivedate= November 8, 2013|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all|accessdate= December 4, 2011}} ==Bibliography== ===Interior work=== ====Comico Comics==== * ''Jezebel Jade'' #1–3 (1988) * ''[[Jonny Quest]]'' #6 (1986) ====DC Comics==== * ''[[Action Comics]]'' #844–846, 851, ''Annual'' #11 (2006–2008) * ''[[Adam Strange]]'' #1–3 (1990) * ''[[Outsiders (comics)|Batman & the Outsiders Special]]'' #1 (2009) * ''[[Batman versus Predator]]'' #1–3 (1992) * ''Clash'' #1–3 (1991–1992) * ''DC Universe: Last Will and Testament'' #1 (2008) * ''[[Doc Savage]]'' #1–4 (1987–1988) * ''[[Justice League]] of America'' vol. 2 #0 (2006) * ''[[Sgt. Rock]]'' #394, 401, 417, 422 (1984–1988) * ''[[Star Trek (DC Comics)|Star Trek]]'' #38 (1987) * ''[[Warlord (comics)|The Warlord]]'' #95, 99–100, ''Annual'' #5 (1985–1986) * ''[[Wednesday Comics]]'' #1–12 (Sgt. Rock) (writer) (2009) ====Marvel Comics==== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * ''[[All-New, All-Different Avengers]]'' #1–3, 7–8, 13–15 (2015–2016) * ''[[Alternative versions of Mary Jane Watson|The Amazing Spider-Man: Renew Your Vows]]'' #1–5 (2015) * ''[[Astonishing Spider-Man & Wolverine]]'' #1–6 (2010–2011) * ''[[AXIS (comics)|Avengers & X-Men: Axis]]'' #1–2, 7 (2014) * ''[[Civil War II]]'' #8 (2016) * ''[[Dark Reign (comics)|Dark Reign: The List – The Amazing Spider-Man]]'' #1 (2010) * ''[[Ghost Rider (Danny Ketch)|Ghost Rider]]/[[Ghost Rider (Johnny Blaze)|Blaze]]: Spirits of Vengeance'' #1–10, 12–13 (1992–1993) * ''[[The Incredible Hulk (comic book)|The Incredible Hulk]]'' vol. 2 #454, -1, 455–456, 458–460, 462–464, 466–467 (1997–1998) * ''The Incredible Hulk'' vol. 3 #87 (2005) * ''[[Mark Hazzard: Merc]]'' #9 (1987) * ''[[Monsters Unleashed (comics)|Monsters Unleashed]]'' #5 (2017) * ''[[Onslaught (comics)|Onslaught: Marvel Universe]]'' #1 (1996) * ''Onslaught: X-Men'' #1 (1996) * ''Origin II'' #1-2, 4–5 (2014) * ''[[The Spectacular Spider-Man]]''#1–6, 297–300, 304- (2017–) * ''[[Ultimate Fantastic Four]]'' #1–6, 13–18 (2004–2005) * ''[[Ultimate X-Men]]'' #1–8, 10–12, 15–17, 20–22, 25, 29, 31–33 (2001–2003) * ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' #339, 368–370, 372–373, 375, 378, 381, 383–384 (1996–2000) * ''[[Age of Apocalypse|Weapon X]]'' #1–4 (1995) * ''[[Wolverine (comic book)|Wolverine]]'' vol. 2 #75, 77–79, 81–82, 85, 87–88, 90, 92–93, 95–97, 100, 102 (1993–1996) * ''Wolverine'' vol. 3 #73–74 (2009) * ''[[X-Men: Legacy|X-Men]]'' vol. 2 #81–84 (1998–1999) * ''[[X-Men 2099]]'' #1–3 (1993) {{div col end}} ===Cover work=== ====Marvel Comics==== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * ''All New Captain America'' #1 (2015) * ''[[All-New Wolverine]]'' #19 (2016) * ''[[All-New X-Men]]'' vol. 2 #1 (2012) * ''[[Astonishing X-Men]]'' vol. 4 #14 (2017) * ''[[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]'' vol. 7 #1 (variant cover only) (2012) * ''[[Blink (comics)|Blink]]'' #1–3 (2001) * ''[[Cable (comics)|Cable]]'' vol. 3 #1 (variant cover only) (2017) * ''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' vol. 3 #25 (variant cover only) (2014) * ''Ghost Rider'' vol. 7 #1 (2015) * ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (2008 team)|Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' vol. 3 #8 (variant cover only) (2013) * ''[[Hellfire Club (comics)|X-Men: hellfire club]]'' #4 (2000) * ''[[Infinity (comic book)|Infinity]]'' #1-6 (2013) * ''[[New Mutants]]'' vol. 3 #6 (2009) * ''Spider-Man/Deadpool'' #1 (variant cover only) (2016) * ''[[Uncanny Avengers]]'' vol. 3 #20-21 (2015) * ''Uncanny X-Men'' #377 (2016) * ''[[Wolverine: Weapon X]]'' #10 (2017) {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Adam Kubert}} * {{comicbookdb|type=creator|id=64|title=Adam Kubert}} * [http://www.kubertschool.edu/faculty/Adam_Kubert.html Adam Kubert] at The Kubert School * [http://www.mikesamazingworld.com/mikes/features/creator.php?creatorid=141 Adam Kubert] at Mike's Amazing World of Comics * [http://www.maelmill-insi.de/UHBMCC/namk19.htm#N591 Adam Kubert] at the Unofficial Handbook of Marvel Comics Creators {{S-start}} {{succession box|title=''[[Ghost Rider (Danny Ketch)|Ghost Rider]]/[[Ghost Rider (Johnny Blaze)|Blaze]]: Spirits of Vengeance'' artist|before=n/a|after=[[Mike Manley (artist)|Mike Manley]]|years=1992–1993}} {{succession box|title=''[[The Incredible Hulk (comic book)|The Incredible Hulk]]'' artist|before=[[Mike Deodato]]|after=[[Javier Pulido]]|years=1997–1998}} {{succession box|title=''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' artist|before=[[Chris {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Amélie Beaury-Saurel | honorific_suffix = | image = Amelie Beaury-Saurel photo.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year|1849}} | birth_place = [[Barcelona]], Spain | death_date = {{Death date and age|1924|05|30|1849||}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = French | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = Painting | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | module = }} '''Amélie Beaury-Saurel''' (1849 – May 30, 1924) was a French painter noted for portraiture.
==Life and career==
Born in [[Barcelona]] as Amélie Beaury, she added "Saurel" to her name in recognition of her mother's family who could trace their lineage to the Byzantine emperors of the 11th-century. Her family lived in Spain and Corsica, but eventually settled in France where she enrolled in the Academie Julian and paid for her studies by carrying out administrative duties and managing the finances.<ref>Madeline, L., ''Women Artists in Paris, 1850-1900,'' Yale University Press, 2017, p.242</ref>
At various times, she was a pupil of [[Jules Joseph Lefebvre|J. Lefebvre]], [[T. Robert-Fleury]] and [[J.P. Laurens]] in [[Académie Julian]], and became a very popular portrait painter, thanks to [[Léon Bonnat]]. She married [[Rodolphe Julian]] in 1895 and took on charge a women's atelier. In her publications, [[Marie Bashkirtseff]] (also a Julian pupil) talked distrustfully about "l'espagnole" (''the Spanish woman''). She made her ''début'' in the ''[[Salon de Paris]]'' in 1874, where she was considered one of the most important artists of the ''Salon'' in 1880.<ref>Yeldham, C., ''Women Artists in Nineteenth-century France and England: Their Art: Volume 1, 1984 "Fig.67 Mlle Amélie Beaury-Saurel also exhibited a self-portrait, a drawing, at the Salon of 1887, a work which received superlative praise. Like Anna Bilinska she was admired for the "virility" of her technique: "On chercherait en vain, parmi les "</ref>
Amélie Beaury-Saurel provided generously most of her mother and sister's necessities. After Julian's death, she bought and laid out "Château Julian", in [[Lapalud]], a village in [[Provence]], in memory of her husband, who had been born there. She died in [[Paris]].
==Awards and recognition==
She was awarded with a Third Medal in the ''Salon'' in 1885 and a Bronze Medal in 1889 [[World's Fair]].<ref>Women artists in nineteenth-century France and England: their art: Volume 1 Charlotte Yeldham - 1984 "Fig.67</ref> Mlle Amélie Beaury-Saurel also exhibited a self-portrait, a drawing, at the Salon of 1887, a work which received superlative praise. Like Anna Bilinska she was admired for the "virility" of her technique.
==Select list of works== *"Christ en croix" de l'Église Saint-Etienne, Issy-les-moulineaux, 1873 *"Portrait d'une femme noire", 1884 *"Le travail de M. Frey, Maître d'armes", prix d'honneur à l'exposition Blanc et Noir de 1891 *"Portrait de Séverine", 1893 *"Dans le bleu", 1894 *"Le repos du modèle", (Musée d'Amiens) *"Portrait de Mme G. C..." *"Jean-Paul Laurens (1838-1921) peintre", 1919. *"Portrait of Gilbert Dupuis", 1922. *"Portrait de [[Léonce Bénédite]] (1859-1925) conservateur du musée du Luxembourg", 1923. ([[Musée d'Orsay]]) *"Portrait d'Alexis Ballot-Beaupré (1836-1917)"
==Gallery==
<gallery> File:Beary-Saurel Jean-Paul Laurens.jpg|Beary-Saurel Jean-Paul Laurens, 1919 File:Beaury-Saurel Dans le bleu (RO 494).jpg|Beaury-Saurel Dans le bleu, 1894 File:Voisin, Felix.JPG|Portrait of M Felix Voisin, 1898 Image:Dupuis par Beaury-Saurel.JPG|Portrait of Gilbert Dupuis </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category|Amélie Beaury-Saurel}}

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/LqzerEX|LqzerEX]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox cave | name = Armintxe Cave | other_name = | photo = | photo_width = 220px | photo_caption = Parietal cave etchngs in the cave | map = Spain Basque Country#Spain | map_caption = location in Spain | map_alt = Armintxe Cave in Spain | relief = yes | location = [[Lekeitio]], [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], [[Spain]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|21|43|N|2|30|29|W|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | land_registry_number = | grid_ref = | depth = | length = | height_variation = | elevation = <!-- | or elevation = --> | discovery = | geology = | lighting = | visitors = no | features = prehistoric [[parietal art]] }} [[File:Armintxeko kobako panela.jpg|alt=The Main Panel, in the day of the discovery.|thumb|220x220px|The Main Panel, in the day of the discovery.]] '''Armintxe Cave''' in [[Lekeitio]] ([[Spain]]) is an important [[Paleolithic]] [[rock art]] site, estimated to date from between 12,000 and 14,500 years ago.<ref name=":0" />
== Location == Armintxe Cave is situated in the Lekeitio municipality of the [[Biscay]] province, in the [[Basque Country (greater area)|Basque Country]], northern Spain.
== Discovery == Although the cave was known from a long time ago, it was believed that it disappeared because of the urbanization and construction works made at the end of the [[20th century]] and beginnings of the [[21st century|21st]]. It was found again and explored on May 1, 2016, by eight [[Speleology|speleologists]] from the Basque group ADES Espeleologia Elkartea. After opening the entrance duct, located on a hillside in an urban environment, the cavers entered unknown galleries, and forced a step to a room where they found the panel of engravings.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://actualid-ades.blogspot.com.es/2017/11/armintxe-archaeological-hydrogeological.html|title=Armintxe: an archaeological, hydrogeological, and diplomatic mess|last=ADES|first=|date=2017-11-13|website=actualid-ades.blogspot.com.es/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref>
== Rock art == Some of these forms and the etching technique used were announced to be "identical" to those found in the [[France|French]] [[Pyrenees]] which suggests that there could have been links between the inhabitants of both areas.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37654544| title = Cave art: Etchings hailed as 'Iberia's most spectacular'| date = 14 October 2016| accessdate = 14 October 2016| publisher = BBC News}}</ref> Already described as a “treasure of humanity.” the depictions are among the largest found to date – some measuring up to {{convert|1.5 |m|ft|2|abbr=on}} in length. A surprise was the first Paleolithic representation of two lions in the region. In a first analysis the etchings were estimated to date from between 12,000 and 14,500 years ago.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.rt.com/viral/362841-basque-ancient-cave-painting/ |title=‘Treasure of humanity': 14,000yo cave paintings found under Spanish town |newspaper=RT Viral |date= |author= |accessdate= December 27, 2016}}</ref>
The main panel is beautifully and masterly carved with animal figures, displayed in a complex composition, suggesting some sort of perspective. All of them have been engraved with the same technique, scratching the soft limestone with the fingers of with a dull point, resulting in very detailed and easy to see figures. The animals are represented with high detail, typical from [[Magdalenian]] art style. Represented animals are horses, bisons, ibex and some carnivores. One of this carnivores has been undoubtly interpreted as a lion, which is an animal rarely present in Magdalenian art. Besides, several sings, including clear claviforms, have been found there. The conventions used for representing animals and the presence of claviforms suggest that the figures could be related to the Late Magdalenian art.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arkeobasque.wordpress.com/2016/10/14/argintxe-a-new-magdalenian-rock-art-site/|title=Armintxe, a new Magdalenian Rock-Art site|last=Rios-Garaizar|first=Joseba|date=2016-10-14|website=arkeobasque.wordpress.com/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref>
Not open to the public, 'extremely difficult to access', located under a residential building in the center of Lekeitio, the need to preserve the paintings outlines the current impossibility to access the artwork.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3837953/50-striking-animal-images-engraved-Spanish-cave-hidden-14-000-years.html |title= 50 'striking' animal images are found engraved in a Spanish cave after being hidden for 14,000 years |newspaper=Daily Mail |date= October 14, 2016 |author=Cheyenne Macdonald, Libby Plummer For Mailonline, Afp |accessdate= December 27, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/spectacular-14500-year-old-lion-etchings-discovered-depth-spanish-cave-1586749 |title=Spain: 'Spectacular' prehistoric lion etchings discovered in Armintxe cave |newspaper=Ibtimes co uk |date= |author= |accessdate= December 27, 2016}}</ref>
[[File:ArmintxeDibujoA3.jpg|thumb|Map of the cave, including the location of the etchings.]]
== Conservation == The cave has a serious problem with floodings, due to construction and urbanization activities which have profoundly altered the course of the underground river. The episodic inundation of most of the galleries of Armintxe has already brought the deterioration of an undetermined part of the artistic heritage it encloses, and threatens to destroy the whole art ensemble. To solve the problem, it is necessary to finish the exploration in order to understand the [[Hydrogeology|hydrogeological]] behaviour of the [[karst]] as a whole; but this exploration is actually paralysed due to disagreements between Administration, archaeologists and speleologists.<ref name=":1" />
==See also== * [[:Category:Caves of Midi-Pyrénées|Caves of Midi-Pyrénées]] * [[Cave of Niaux]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Navbox prehistoric caves}}
[[Category:Prehistoric art]] [[Category:Caves of Spain]]

revision.comment: /* External links */HTTP→HTTPS for [[The New York Times]]. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Association of Art Museum Directors''' (AAMD) is an organization of [[art museum]] directors from the United States, Canada, and Mexico.
The AAMD was established in 1916 by the directors of twelve American museums and was formally incorporated in 1969.<ref name=AAMD>{{cite web|title=Mission|url=https://aamd.org/about/mission|work=Association of Art Museum Directors|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> It currently has 220 members.<ref name=AAMD2>{{cite web|title=Membership|url=https://aamd.org/about/mission|work=Association of Art Museum Directors|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref>
The Association of Art Museum Directors aims "to support its members in increasing the contribution of art museums to society" by promoting professional standards of practice, facilitating education, and advocating for museums.<ref name=AAMD />
AAMD's policies and guidelines are developed by its members, and issues publications that prescribe professional practices for art museums, from [[Collection_(artwork)#Accessioning|accessioning]] and [[Collection_(artwork)#Deaccessioning|deaccessioning]],<ref name=AAMD3>{{cite web|title=Art Museums, Private Collectors, and the Public Benefit|url=https://aamd.org/sites/default/files/document/PrivateCollectors3.pdf|work=Association of Art Museum Directors|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> to ethics<ref>{{cite web|title=Good Governance and Non-Profit Integrity|url=https://aamd.org/sites/default/files/document/Good%20Governance_Final%2006.06.pdf|work=Association of Art Museum Directors'|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> and censorship.<ref>{{cite news|last=Knight|first=Christopher|title=Art museum directors issue stern Smithsonian rebuke|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2010/12/art-museum-directors-issue-smithsonian-rebuke.html|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=L.A. Times|date=December 3, 2010}}</ref>
== See also == *[[List of female art museum directors]] *[[List of museums]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.aamd.org/ Association website] * [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2008/12/national-academ.html Los Angeles Times on AAMD's stance on deaccessioning] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/04/arts/design/04coll.html?fta=y NY Times on AAMD's stance on the acquisition of archaeological material and ancient art]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Association Of Art Museum Directors}} [[Category:Arts organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1916]] [[Category:1916 establishments in the United States]]
{{US-arts-org-stub}}

{{infobox organization | name = Books Through Bars | logo = booskthroughbars.png | alt = Logo of Books Through Bars | headquarters = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], [[United States of America|U.S.]] | status = [[501(c)(3)]] [[nonprofit organization]] | mission = To facilitate prisoner self-education by providing quality books to dozens of prison libraries and hundreds of individual prisoners, many of whom lack library access.<ref name= 990-2015>"[http://www.guidestar.org/FinDocuments/2016/232/841/2016-232841845-0d632d8b-Z.pdf Form 990-EZ: Short Form Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax]". ''Books Through Bars''. [[Guidestar]]. September 30, 2016.</ref> | tax_id = 23-2841845<ref name= irseos/> | founded = {{start date and age|1990}}| founder = [[New Society Publishers]] | slogan = Books. Knowledge. Change. | revenue = $53,129<ref name= 990-2015/> | revenue_year = 2016 | expenses = $48,925<ref name= 990-2015/> | expenses_year = 2016 | leader_name = Brielle Talarico<ref name= 990-2015/> | leader_title = [[President (corporation)|President]] | services = Distributes free books and educational materials to incarcerated people in [[Pennsylvania]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York State|New York]], [[Maryland]], [[Delaware]], [[Virginia]], and [[West Virginia]].<ref>"[http://booksthroughbars.org/ Our work changes hearts, minds and lives]". ''Books Through Bars''. Retrieved December 15, 2017.</ref> | website = {{URL|www.booksthroughbars.org}} }} '''Books Through Bars''' is an [[United States|American]] organization that works to provide quality reading material to prisoners in [[Pennsylvania]] and surrounding states. [[New Society Publishers]] of [[Philadelphia]] founded Books Through Bars in 1990.<ref name= history>"[http://booksthroughbars.org/about/history/ History]". ''Books Through Bars''. Retrieved December 15, 2017.</ref> Books Through Bars was separately incorporated as a nonprofit organization on March 19, 2001.<ref>"[https://www.corporations.pa.gov/search/CorpSearch Books Through Bars: Entity Number 2994731]". ''Business Entity Details''. Pennsylvania Department of State. Retrieved December 15, 2017.</ref> There are approximately 30 similar, but unaffiliated, organizations throughout the United States.
Because prisoners in American [[prison]]s are not able to receive books from sources other than recognized publishers, bookstores, or other legitimate distributors, those without the financial resources to buy books have very limited access to them. Prison libraries are not being funded, in part because reading material is widely seen as irrelevant to a "mostly uneducated and indeed largely illiterate prison population".<ref name=Scalia>{{cite web|last1=Scalia|first1=Antonin|title=Lewis v. Casey (94-1511), 516 U.S. 804 (1996)|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/94-1511.ZO.html|website=Legal Information Institute|publisher=School of Law, Cornell University|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref> New Society Publishers began its program after it began receiving letters from indigent prisoners, and provides donated books to individual prisoners, prison libraries, and [[halfway house]]s.<ref name=Donating>{{cite web|title=Donating Books|url=http://booksthroughbars.org/donate/books/|website=Books Through Bars|accessdate=30 June 2014|quote=Dropping off books... Book condition... Books we need most... Books we don’t need}}</ref> The organization distributes several hundred packages per month. It also sponsors regular public events relating to issues such as [[human rights]], the [[war on drugs]], and [[prison reform]].
Books Through Bars is a [[501(c)(3)]] nonprofit organization,<ref name= irseos>"[https://apps.irs.gov/app/eos/pub78Search.do?ein1=23-2841845&names=&city=&state=All...&country=US&deductibility=all&dispatchMethod=searchCharities&submitName=Search Books Through Bars]". ''Exempt Organizations Select Check''. [[Internal Revenue Service]]. Retrieved December 15, 2017.</ref> formally organized as a collective and run by nine core members plus about twenty volunteers, and it is supported by grants from charitable organizations.<ref name= history /> Books Through Bars is entirely run and operated by unpaid volunteers.<ref name= 990-2015/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.booksthroughbars.org/}} * "[https://web.archive.org/web/20050414122841/http://www.citypaper.net/articles/011896/article007.shtml Building Blocks]". ''Philadelphia City Paper''. January 18, 1996. Archived from [http://www.citypaper.net/articles/011896/article007.shtml the original] on April 14, 2005. *[http://www.newsociety.com/ New Society Publishers]
[[Category:Book promotion]] [[Category:Charities based in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1990]] [[Category:Prison charities based in the United States]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Railway accidents in the United Kingdom‎ to [[:Category:Railway accidents and incidents in the United Kingdom‎]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 March 27]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} There are a number of '''books on British railway accidents''' which provide aid in the systematic study of the causes and effects of accidents, and their prevention. There are common themes in many accidents (see [[Classification of railway accidents|Classification]]). Key books are listed here to avoid repeating them for each individual accident.
The [[doyen]] is [[L. T. C. Rolt]]'s ''Red for Danger'', first published in 1956, which takes a wide-ranging overview of over 100 accidents. Most other books concentrate on a smaller number of specific accidents, described in more detail. O.S. Nock's "Historic Railway Disasters" combines both approaches, with individual chapters on especially significant accidents such as [[Armagh rail disaster|Armagh]] and [[Quintinshill rail crash|Quintinshill]]. For accidents in the last 30 years and modern operating practice, Stanley Hall's four books are particularly good. Apart from Schneider and Mase (1968/1970) and Faith (2001), all the books below are confined to British accidents.
The list below does not include books on individual accidents; for these, see [[Tay Bridge disaster|Tay Bridge]], [[Quintinshill rail crash|Quintinshill]], [[Harrow and Wealdstone rail crash|Harrow]], [[Hixon rail crash|Hixon]], [[Moorgate tube crash|Moorgate]] and [[Lockington rail crash|Lockington]].
An extremely valuable source now on the Internet is the Railways Archive compilation of official Railway Inspectorate Accident Reports - see "External Links" below.
==Key books== * {{cite book | first=Nicholas | last=Faith | year=2001 | title=Derail: Why Trains Crash | edition=2nd | publisher= Channel 4 Books | isbn=0-7522-1987-1 }} First published 1998 to accompany the Channel 4 series. An overall survey like Rolt's, but covering worldwide accidents. * {{cite book | first=Stanley | last=Hall | year=1987 | title=Danger Signals: an investigation into modern railway accidents | publisher= Ian Allan | isbn= 0-7110-1704-2}} A broad survey, concentrating especially on accidents in the 20 years up to 1986, especially those caused by drivers' and signalmen's errors. * {{cite book | first=Stanley | last=Hall | year=1991 | title=Danger on the Line | publisher= Ian Allan | isbn= 0-7110-1872-3}} Covers Clapham Junction, Purley, Glasgow Bellgrove and a wide range of other accidents, e.g. track problems, fires, staff fatalities. * {{cite book | first=Stanley | last=Hall | year=1999 | title=Hidden Dangers | publisher=Ian Allan | isbn=0-7137-1973-7 }} Covers the period 1989-97 including Cowden, Newton and Southall. * {{cite book | first=Stanley | last=Hall | year=2003 | title=Beyond Hidden Dangers: Railway Safety into the 21st Century | publisher=Ian Allan | isbn=0-7110-2915-6 }}. Includes Ladbroke Grove, Hatfield, Potters Bar, Great Heck (Selby). * {{cite book | first=J.A.B. | last=Hamilton. | year=1967 | title=British Railway Accidents of the 20th Century (reprinted 1987 as Disaster down the Line). | publisher=George Allen and Unwin / Javelin Books | isbn=0-7137-1973-7 }} Covers 27 accidents between 1905 and 1962. Particularly good on the human factor and psychological reasons behind accidents. * {{cite book | first=O.S. | last=Nock | year=1980 | title=Historic Railway Disasters | edition=2nd | publisher= Ian Allan }} First published 1966, another well-written classic. * {{cite book | first=L.T.C. | last=Rolt | year=1956 | title=Red for Danger | edition= | publisher= Bodley Head / David and Charles / Pan Books }} An excellent overview of accidents up to 1957, in fine writing style. An early reviewer wrote, "At the risk of being thought callous, one must praise Mr Rolt for making death and disaster most attractive reading". Several revised and updated editions published (1960, 1966, 1976, 1982). Later editions have material added by G.M. Kichenside. * {{cite book | first=Ascanio | last=Schneider |author2=Armand Mase | year=1968 | title=Katastrophen auf Schienen. (In German) | publisher= Orell Fussli Verlag }} * {{cite book | first=Ascanio | last=Schneider |author2=Armand Mase | year=1970 | title=Railway Accidents of (Great Britain and) Europe. Translated from German (book above) by E.L. Dellow | publisher= David and Charles | isbn=0-7153-4791-8 }} Includes [[Classification of railway accidents|classification]] and numerous European accidents. * {{cite book | first=Adrian | last=Vaughan | year=1989 | title=Obstruction Danger | publisher= Guild Publishing | isbn=1-85260-055-1 }} Written by a former signalman, with an interesting selection including some less well-known mishaps. * {{cite book | year=1996 | title=British Railway Disasters | publisher=Ian Allan | isbn=0-7110-2470-7 }} covers 47 accidents between 1876 and 1991 with many photographs. * {{cite book | first=Adrian | last=Vaughan | year=2000 | title=Tracks to Disaster | publisher= Ian Allan | isbn=0-7110-2731-5 }} 19 modern accidents in the period 1975-97. Like his previous book, contains some trenchant comments on railway management.
==External links== *[http://www.railwaysarchive.co.uk/listing.php?PHPSESSID=6a3f8d82df26a7e7b93812055ff97a3f&showSearch=true&sortKey=date&sortDirection=ASC&text=&startYear=all&endYear=all&event=all&development=all&category=4&author=all&publisher=all&published=yes&submit=Go Railway Archive- Accident Report]. *[http://catskillarchive.com/rrextra/wkbktoc.Html Early railways in the UK and USA by Charles Adams (published in 1879)] *[http://www.rail-reg.gov.uk/server/show/nav.1112 Office of the Railway Regulator] Reports on major incidents *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080915212426/http://www.raib.gov.uk/publications/index.cfm UK Rail Accident Investigation Branch] Publications - Covers the period from 2006 onward. Note as well as major accidents there are reports on relatively minor incidents.
[[Category:Railway accidents and incidents in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Lists of books]] [[Category:British railway-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=November 2014}} [[File:Chalcography.PNG|thumb|266px|Chalcography technology, plate of German ''poeta laureatus'' Ambrosius Hannemann (died in 1644)]]
'''Chalcography''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] chalcos, copper and graphia, to write), are engravings on [[copper]] plates used for printmaking and for illustrations in the production of books. The ''[[Monte dei Santi di Dio]]'' by [[Antonio Bettini]] is the most ancient book bearing chalcographies, printed in [[Florence]] on September 10, 1477 from [[Nicolo di Lorenzo Tedesco]]. Its primacy is contested by [[Ptolemy]]'s ''[[Geography (Ptolemy)|Cosmographia]]'', printed in [[Bologna]] on June 23, 1477 from [[Domenico de' Lapi]], a [[Latin]] translation from [[Jacopo d'Angelo]], containing geographical charts and maps by [[Taddeo Crivelli]], engraved in copper plates.
== See also == * [[Lithography]] * [[Printmaking]]
{{art-stub}}
[[Category:Printmaking]] [[Category:Book collecting]] [[Category:Reading (process)]] [[Category:Planographic printing]] [[Category:Communication design]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Casse-tête chinois | image = Casse-tête_chinois_poster.jpg | caption = Official poster | director = [[Cédric Klapisch]] | producer = [[Bruno Levy]]
Buzz Koenig | writer = Cédric Klapisch | starring = [[Romain Duris]]
[[Audrey Tautou]]
[[Cécile de France]]
[[Kelly Reilly]] | music = Christophe Minck
[[Kraked Unit]] | cinematography = [[Natasha Braier]] | editing = [[Anne-Sophie Bion]] | distributor = [[StudioCanal]] | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2013|10|16}} | runtime = 117 minutes | country = France | language = French
English | budget = €17.3 million{{cite web|url=http://destinationcine.com/box-office/les-14-films-francais-qui-ont-franchi-le-million-dentrees-en-2013/|title=Les 14 films français qui ont franchi le million d’entrées en 2013|work=Destination ciné}} | gross = $17 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=chinesepuzzle.htm |title=Chinese Puzzle (2014) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2014-01-03}} }} '''''Chinese Puzzle''''' ({{lang-fr|'''Casse-tête chinois'''}}) is a 2013 French [[comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Cédric Klapisch]]. It is the third chapter of the ''Spanish Apartment trilogy'', after ''[[L'Auberge Espagnole]]'' (2002) and ''[[Russian Dolls (film)|Les Poupées russes]] ''(''Russian Dolls'', 2005). ==Plot== Ten years have passed, and the once happy lovers, Xavier Rousseau ([[Romain Duris]]) and Wendy ([[Kelly Reilly]]), have split. When she moves with their two children to New York City, he also moves to there to be near the children. Wendy now lives with John ([[Peter Hermann (actor)|Peter Hermann]]) in a luxury apartment overlooking Central Park. Xavier initially stays with Isabelle ([[Cécile de France]]) and Ju ([[Sandrine Holt]]), a lesbian couple whose child he fathered, but he soon finds his own apartment above a Chinese bakery where he works on a new novel assisted by brief visions of [[Arthur Schopenhauer]] and [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]]. Having no work visa, Xavier is advised by his lawyer ([[Jason Kravits]]) to seek illegal employment and marry for a green card. After saving his taxicab driver from a vicious beating, the driver's grateful Chinese-American family agrees to have Xavier marry one of their relations, Nancy ([[Li Jun Li]]), who is amenable and complicit. His former French girlfriend, Martine ([[Audrey Tautou]]), visits him while on a business trip and returns a second time with her own two children on spring break. Xavier and Martine briefly attempt to rekindle their relationship. The film climaxes when the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] performs a surprise inspection of Xavier's apartment while Isabelle is using it to cheat on Ju with their babysitter ([[Flore Bonaventura]]). Later as Martine is departing for home with her kids, Xavier races on foot to catch her shuttle bus, confess his love, and demand that she stay and live with him. She agrees. The film concludes with the cast of characters walking in a celebratory parade down a Chinatown street. ==Cast== * [[Romain Duris]] as Xavier Rousseau * [[Kelly Reilly]] as Wendy * [[Audrey Tautou]] as Martine * [[Cécile de France]] as Isabelle * [[Sandrine Holt]] as Ju * [[Flore Bonaventura]] as Isabelle the babysitter * [[Jochen Hägele]] as Hegel * [[Benoît Jacquot]] as Xavier's father * [[Martine Demaret]] as Xavier's mother * [[Dominique Besnehard]] as the editor * [[Zinedine Soualem]] as Mr. Boubaker * [[Peter Hermann (actor)|Peter Hermann]] as John * [[Jason Kravits]] as Xavier's lawyer * [[Vanessa Guide]] as the nurse * [[Kyan Khojandi]] as Antoine Garceau * [[Li Jun Li]] as Nancy * [[Pablo Mugnier-Jacob]] as Tom * [[Margaux Mansart]] as Mia * [[Adrian Martinez (actor)|Adrian Martinez]] as Le patron coursier == Reception and awards == The film garnered favourable reviews. It scored a 75% 'certified fresh' rating on review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 61 reviews, with the consensus stating "Pleasantly easygoing and consistently funny, Chinese Puzzle offers a suitably endearing conclusion to Cédric Klapisch's Trilogy of Xavier." At [[Metacritic]], it has a score of 64 which is based on 24 critics, indicating "Generally favorable reviews". The film was nominated for the [[César Award for Best Music Written for a Film|Best Music award]] at the [[39th César Awards]],{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/frances-cesar-awards-nominations-announced-675607 |title=Berenice Bejo, Lea Seydoux, Roman Polanski Among France's Cesar Awards Nominees |accessdate=1 February 2014 |work=Hollywood Reporter}} and came second for the Audience Award for Best Narrative Feature at the''' '''57th [[San Francisco International Film Festival]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links == * {{IMDb title|1937118}} * {{mojo title|chinesepuzzle}} * [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/chinese_puzzle_2013/ ''Chinese Puzzle''] at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] * [http://www.metacritic.com/movie/chinese-puzzle ''Chinese Puzzle''] at [[Metacritic]] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g2LzDqTIxEQ Official US trailer (Cohen Media Group)] * [http://cohenmedia.net/Details.aspx?id=ce063aa0-0709-e311-9060-d4ae527c3b65 Official US site (Cohen Media Group)] {{Cédric Klapisch}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chinese Puzzle}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Cédric Klapisch]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French comedy-drama films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] {{2010s-France-film-stub}} {{2010s-romantic-comedy-film-stub}}

page.title: Chorus of the elderly in classical Greek drama

revision.text:
The '''chorus of the elderly in classical Greek drama''' is a common [[Trope (literature)|trope]] in the [[Theatre of ancient Greece|theater of that period]]. Out of the thirty or so plays that are extant from the classical period, seven have choruses that consist of elderly people.<ref>Falkner, Thomas M. ''The Poetics of Old Age in Greek Epic, Lyric and Tragedy''.Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1995.242</ref> Choruses in ancient drama often provided some moralizing lesson to the protagonist, especially in tragedy. However, the figures of the elderly chorus often seem to imply a traditional way of thinking that has become outdated with time, or, in some cases, provide a model of inefficacy. As history progressed from the early stages of Greek drama (with Aeschylus) the chorus became more integrated with the happenings on stage, rendering the chorus a messenger between the world of the audience and that of the actors.<ref>[[H. D. F. Kitto|Kitto, H.D.F.]] ''Greek Tragedy'' London: Methuen, 1939. 55</ref>
== Tragedy == The chorus of the elderly within tragedy is often used as an exemplar of old social mores. They are often ineffectual at admonishing main actors or interfering with the main plot. Sophocles in ''Oedipus at Colonus'' uses the chorus to relate to the aging protagonist, who has wandered to the town for safety. A common trope is that the elderly chorus provides sympathy and empathy for those in need as they too are in a deteriorating state, nearing their doom.<ref>Falkner, 242.</ref> The chorus of elders not only attempt to protect Oedipus but fail miserably; while the chorus speaks aggressively it is well known that they are too frail to attempt any sort of defense of the protagonist from physical harm. Similar outcomes of choral interference with onstage happenings occur in many other plays, including Agamemnon. Falkner notes that in tragedy the elderly are presented as [[Quixotism|quixotic]] and obsessed with the prospect of doom inherent in old age; he also notes that often the elderly are presented as mourners within plays, perhaps relating to the number of sorrows old age allows one to accrue in mind.<ref>Falkner, 178</ref>
== Comedy == Aristophanes uses the chorus of the elderly for varying reasons within his comedies. For example, the chorus of the elderly within ''The Wasps'' plays both a comedic role and also serves as a political counterfoil to the young, cosmopolitans of Athens.<ref>Wencis, Leonard. ''The Social Significance of Youth in New Comedy'' Ann Arbor: University Microfilms, 1973.</ref>
== Plays == *''[[The Wasps]]'' *''[[Lysistrata]]'' *''[[Oedipus Rex]]'' *''[[Orestes (play)|Orestes]]'' *''[[The Suppliants (Euripides)|The Suppliants]]'' *''[[Agamemnon (play)|Agamemnon]]'' *''[[Alcestis (play)|Alcestis]]'' *''[[Heracleidae (play)|Heracleidae]]''
== References ==
<references/>
[[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]]
